IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: the statement of purpose of the detroit zoological society is celebrating and saving wildlife.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: DESCRIPTION OF INTENDED USES OF ENDOWMENT FUNDS
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY (SOCIETY) ENDOWMENTS WERE ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE A STABLE SOURCE OF FUNDING TO HELP UNDERWRITE THE PROGRAMS AND FACILITIES OF THE DETROIT ZOO AND BELLE ISLE NATURE ZOO. MONIES PLACED IN ENDOWMENTS ARE INVESTED, WITH INTEREST, AND ONLY DISTRIBUTED AS DICTATED BY THE SOCIETY'S ENDOWMENT GOVERNING POLICY. FUNDS MAY BE ESTABLISHED BY DONORS WITHIN EACH ENDOWMENT. A NAMED FUND REQUIRES A MINIMUM INVESTMENT OF $100,000 AND THE REVENUE MAY BE RESTRICTED BY THE DONORS. THE SOCIETY'S ENDOWMENTS CONSIST OF FIFTEEN INDIVIDUAL FUNDS ESTABLISHED FOR A VARIETY OF PURPOSES. THE ENDOWMENTS OF THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: THE ENDOWMENT FOR AMPHIBIAN CONSERVATION: THE ENDOWMENT FOR AMPHIBIAN CONSERVATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO SUPPORT AMPHIBIAN EDUCATION, RESEARCH, CONSERVATION AND THE PROPAGATION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES. THE ENDOWMENT FOR EDUCATION: THE ENDOWMENT FOR EDUCATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999. THE ENDOWMENT IS USED TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AT THE DETROIT ZOO AND BELLE ISLE NATURE ZOO. FUND: THE WILLIAM RANDOLPH HEARST FOUNDATION FUND: THE HEARST FUND WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2001. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO PROVIDE MONIES FOR SCHOLARSHIPS AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS OF THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY. FUND: THE STANDARD FEDERAL BANK ENDOWMENT FUND FOR EDUCATION: THE STANDARD FEDERAL FUND WAS ESTABLISHED MARCH 31, 2004 BY THE STANDARD FEDERAL BANK OF TROY, MICHIGAN. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO PROVIDE MONIES FOR EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT THE BELLE ISLE NATURE ZOO. FUND: THE SAMUEL L. WESTERMAN CHILDREN ADMISSIONS FUND: THE WESTERMAN FUND WAS ESTABLISHED DECEMBER 1, 2007 BY JAMES H. LOPRETE FAMILY. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO SUBSIDIZE ZOO ADMISSIONS FOR CHILDREN OF LOW INCOME FAMILIES. THE MADELEINE BERMAN ACADEMY FOR HUMANE EDUCATION ENDOWMENT: THE MADELEINE BERMAN ACADEMY FOR HUMAN EDUCATION ENDOWMENT WAS ESTABLISHED SEPTEMBER 13, 2001 BY MADELEINE AND MANDELL L. BERMAN. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO SUPPORT OPERATIONAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH HUMANE EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT THE DETROIT ZOO IN FUTURE YEARS. FUND: THE JOHN S. AND JAMES L. KNIGHT FUND: THE KNIGHT FUND WAS ESTABLISHED DECEMBER 13, 1999 BY THE JOHN S. AND JAMES L. KNIGHT FOUNDATION. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO SUPPORT THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS OF THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY. THE SOCIETY DETERMINED THAT IT WOULD BE MOST BENEFICIAL AS A COMPONENT OF THE HUMANE EDUCATION ENDOWMENT. FUND: THE ADELYN B. DEVEREAUX FUND: THE DEVEREAUX FUND WAS ESTABLISHED DECEMBER 28, 2001 THROUGH MRS. ADELYN B. DEVEREAUX'S TRUST AGREEMENT. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO BENEFIT THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S ENDOWMENT FUND. THE SOCIETY DETERMINED THAT IT WOULD BE MOST BENEFICIAL AS A COMPONENT OF THE HUMANE EDUCATION ENDOWMENT. THE RICHARD AND JANE MANOOGIAN ENDOWMENT FOR WILDLIFE ART AND INTERPRETATION: THE RICHARD AND JANE MANOOGIAN ENDOWMENT FOR WILDLIFE ART AND INTERPRETATION WAS ESTABLISHED MAY 6, 2002 BY RICHARD A. MANOOGIAN. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND MAINTAIN WORKS OF ART, INCLUDING SCULPTURE, AT THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL PARK. IN ADDITION, EARNINGS WILL SUPPORT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS FOCUSING ON THE INTERPRETATION OF ART THAT EXPLORES THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HUMANS AND ANIMALS. THE ENDOWMENT FOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY: THE ENDOWMENT FOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL NEEDS DRIVEN BY THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S MISSION OF CELEBRATING AND SAVING WILDLIFE. THE ENDOWMENT FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION: THE ENDOWMENT FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO SUPPORT THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S COMMITMENT TO SPECIES PRESERVATION. THE ENDOWMENT FOR THE ZOO: THE ENDOWMENT FOR THE ZOO WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1999. THE PURPOSE OF THE ENDOWMENT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE ONGOING IMPROVEMENT OF THE PROGRAMS, ANIMAL HABITATS, PICTURESQUE GROUNDS, FACILITIES AND OPERATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE. FUND: THE JOYCE H. COHN MEMORIAL FUND (DIRECTOR DISCRETIONARY FUND): THE COHN FUND WAS ESTABLISHED ON MARCH 8, 1990 BY THE UNITED JEWISH CHARITIES, ON BEHALF OF MRS. IRWIN I. COHN, RITA AND JOHN HADDOW, JUDGE AVERN COHN AND FAMILY IN MEMORY OF JOYCE H. COHN. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO PROVIDE DISCRETIONARY INCOME FOR THE ZOO'S DIRECTOR TO PERMIT THE ZOO AND/OR ITS STAFF TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR WHICH NO BUDGETED FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE. FUND: THE GERRY RISSMAN PLAYSCAPE FUND: THE PLAYSCAPE FUND WAS ESTABLISHED DECEMBER 28, 1998 BY THE HARRY B. AND ANNA KORMAN FOUNDATION. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO SUPPORT THE ONGOING MAINTENANCE AND UPGRADES OF THE GERRY RISSMAN PLAYSCAPE. FUND: THE SOUTHEASTERN MICHIGAN VETERINARY ASSOCIATION (SEMVMA) FUND: THE SEMVMA FUND WAS ESTABLISHED ON JANUARY 15, 2002 BY THE SOUTHEASTERN MICHIGAN VETERINARY ASSOCIATION. THE PURPOSE OF THE FUND IS TO PROVIDE LONG-TERM FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S HOSPITAL NEEDS.

IN JULY 2006, FASB INTERPRETATION NO.(FIN)48, ACCOUNTING FOR UNCERTAINTY IN INCOME TAXES, AN INTERPRETATION OF FASB STATEMENT NO. 109, ACCOUNTING FOR INCOME TAXES (CODIFIED IN ASC 740, INCOME TAXES), WAS ISSUED. ON APRIL 1, 2009, THE SOCIETY ADOPTED FIN 48. THE ADOPTION OF FIN 48 DID NOT HAVE AN IMPACT ON THE SOCIETY'S FINANCIAL POSITION AND RESULT OF OPERATIONS.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: reconciliation of change in net assets from form 990 to financials
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Total other adjustments consist of: capital expenditures, included on afs, not on form 990 revenue section (1,532,859) fundraising expenses, on form 990 revenue section, not on AFS 186,579 --------- total (1,346,280)

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: reconciliation of revenue per afs with revenue per return
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The (186,579) is fundraising expenses on the 990 revenue section and not on the audited financial statements.

Form990ScheduleFPartIV.Identifier: Organization's Procedures for Monitoring Use of Grant Funds Outside the US
Form990ScheduleFPartIV.Explanation: THE ADOPT-A-SCHOOL PROGRAM RECEIVES INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT. THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY ACCEPTS DONATIONS FROM SUPPORTERS WORLDWIDE AND TRANSFERS THE FUNDS IN THEIR ENTIRETY DOWN TO OUR PARTNERS IN PERU. A REPRESENTATIVE FROM THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY PARTICIPATES IN THE DELIVERY OF SCHOOL SUPPLIES EACH APRIL, PROVIDING A FIRST-HAND ACCOUNT OF THE PURCHASED SUPPLIES AND THEIR DISTRIBUTION. TWO TRIPS WERE FACILTATED TO THE AMAZON RAINFOREST IN APRIL 2009. 4,500 STUDENTS RECEIVED BASIC SCHOOL SUPPLIES. PARTICIPANTS BUILT A WATER PURIFICATION TOWER AND BAKERY IN THE COMMUNITY OF IRLANDA.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: NON REMOVABLE PROPERTY OF THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY IS OWNED BY THE CITY OF DETROIT, A RESIDENTIAL HOME IS LOCATED ON THE GROUNDS OF THE ZOO. THE CEO/EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE ZOO IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN THIS RESIDENCE. During the taxable year Rosemary K. Watkins separated from the Detroit Zoological Society and received severance pay in the amount of $9507.70.

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Demonstrate leadership in wildlife conservation and animal welfare. Provide a broad audience with outstanding and unique educational opportunities that lead to the appreciation and stewardship of nature. Inspire our community with engaging, meaningful and memorable experiences. Provide innovative zoological facilities that contribute to the region's economic vitality. Demonstrate organizational excellence consistent with a commitment to outstanding service, progressive resource management and environmental leadership.

The Detroit Zoological Society (DZS) continues its mission of Celebrating and Saving Wildlife by demonstrating leadership in wildlife conservation and animal welfare. The DZS was involved with the following animal rescues during the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year. LIFE AFTER FINSH LINE FOR RACEHORSE AT DETROIT ZOO. The DZS is providing a retired racehorse named Trio a permanent home in which to live out his golden years. The chestnut Thoroughbred gelding galloped into the Detroit Zoo's barnyard just in time for his 10th birthday on Kentucky Derby day in 2009. ANOTHER RESCUED RACEHORSE CANTERS INTO DETROIT ZOO. The DZS added another rescued racehorse to its stable. Buster, a 5-year-old Thoroughbred gelding whose racing career ended after only four races due to an injury, is now living the good life in the Detroit Zoo's barnyard. RESCUED HARP SEAL FINDS NEW HOME AT DETROIT ZOO. The DZS is providing a permanent home at the Detroit Zoo's Arctic Ring of Life for a male harp seal found on a beach in Massachusetts. An examination by veterinarians at Mystic Aquarium revealed that the seal had congenital blindness and likely would not survive if returned to the ocean. The Detroit Zoo was chosen to care for the seal because of its high standards of animal care and the fact that it is the only zoo in the United States to care for harp seals. ANIMALS RESCUED IN TEXAS ARRIVE AT DETROIT ZOO. The DZS played an important role in the largest exotic animal rescue effort in the history of the United States, providing expert assistance in the care of more than 27,000 animals seized in a raid on U.S. Global Exotics, an international exotic animal dealer in Texas. The Detroit Zoo is providing sanctuary for many exotic mammals - including wallabies, sloths, ring-tailed lemurs and coatis - as well as hundreds of reptiles, spiders and amphibians. In addition, the DZS helped to place hundreds more rescued animals in other accredited zoos and sanctuaries throughout the country. The following significant births occurred at the Detroit Zoo during the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year. AARDVARK ARRIVES AT DETROIT ZOO. An aardvark, believed to be a male, was born at the Detroit Zoo. Due to the aardvark's clumsy nature, veterinary and zookeeper staff assisted with raising the fragile baby aardvark to prevent the possibility of injury. CUTE PAIR JOINS LEMUR LAIR AT DETROIT ZOO. Twin black-and-white ruffed lemurs were born at the Detroit Zoo. Black-and-white ruffed lemurs are a critically endangered species from one of the most at-risk habitats on earth. DETROIT ZOO'S NEW BABIES SHAKE THINGS UP. Nine eastern Massassauga rattlesnakes were born on exhibit at the Holden Museum of Living Reptiles, the third successful breeding of the species in the past decade at the Detroit Zoo. The eastern Massassauga rattlesnake, Michigan's only venomous reptile, is considered a "species of special concern" by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources and is protected by state law. THE DETROIT ZOO HAS BRED A PANDA THAT'S RED. A male red panda was born at the Detroit Zoo. Red pandas are listed as "vulnerable" on the International Union for Conservation of Nature's Red List of Threatened Species. DETROIT ZOO'S BABY PUDU IS A 'DEER'. A male pudu, the world's smallest species of deer, was born at the Detroit Zoo. There are less than 30 pudus in U.S. zoos. The Detroit Zoological Society welcomed the following new arrivals during the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year. SEE WHAT EVERYONE IS 'TAKIN' ABOUT AT THE DETROIT ZOO. The Detroit Zoo has joined a short list of North American zoos caring for takins in captivity with the addition of brothers Kalden and Deshi. The Sichuan takin - sometimes referred to as a goat antelope - is a large, ox-like animal with a body like a bison, a nose like a moose, horns like a wildebeest and a tail like a bear. NEW POLAR BEAR AT DETROIT ZOO HAS A NEED TO BREED. The Detroit Zoo has welcomed a 9-year-old, 900-pound male polar bear from the Lincoln Park Zoo as a suitor for one of its females. Lee arrived at the Zoo with a breeding recommendation from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) Species Survival Plan (SSP) program, a cooperative management plan to ensure genetically healthy, diverse and self-sustaining populations of threatened and endangered species. BELTED BOVINE A SWEET ADDITION TO DETROIT ZOO. A recent addition to the Detroit Zoo's barnyard is a 1-year-old belted Galloway steer. Commonly referred to as a beltie, the steer resembles a giant Oreo cookie with a creamy-white midsection sandwiched between jet-black front and hind quarters. YOU OTTER SEE WHAT'S NEW AT THE DETROIT ZOO. A 3-year-old male North American river otter has joined the Detroit Zoo. The North American river otter is an aquatic mammal native to Michigan. CONSERVATION HIGHLIGHTS DETROIT ZOO BREEDS RECORD 3,701 PUERTO RICAN CRESTED TOADS. The Detroit Zoo's breeding program for the critically endangered Puerto Rican crested toad has yielded the best results in 10 years with 3,701 tadpoles. The Zoo kept 20 tadpoles for future breeding at the National Amphibian Conservation Center and shipped the rest to Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico, for release into the wild. The Detroit Zoo has been working to preserve the Puerto Rican crested toad since 1999.

The Detroit Zoological Society continues to provide a broad audience with outstanding and unique educational opportunities that lead to the appreciation and stewardship of nature. Listed below are some of the educational opportunities provided to our visitors during the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year. ENGAGING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS - 34,239 guests participated in 1,214 programs inclusive of youth, scout, overnights, field trips, docent-led tours, outreach and educator escapes. A "Girl's Night Out" overnight was held in recognition of Women's History Month in March. Africa Adventure stories: The program held at the Ford Education Center is an intergenerational program which immerses audiences into an African rural setting listening to real-life African stories of growing up in Africa and the challenges faced before adulthood. Guests are also taught to play African drums and African music. There are two sessions per day. Savannah/Serengeti trails: Young adults are introduced into wild Africa at the Ford Education Center Discovery Studio with tales of living amongst wild animals before touring the Zoo's African Grasslands. Participants learn the art of tracking animals using various clues such as animal tracks, droppings, lairs and fur. They learn to appreciate nature and all that pertains to it. Biofacts including animals' bones and skins are also used to educate the audience. HUMANE EDUCATION - The Madeleine Berman Academy for Humane Education was created in 2002 to help people help animals. The Academy uses a variety of teaching strategies - from traditional instruction to storytelling, role-playing, theater and virtual technology - to educate audiences about the need to treat all living creatures with empathy, respect and gentleness. Humane education is one of many unique DZS features. As a central value it provides the lens through which programs are developed. The goal of humane education is to instill a desire to make a positive difference for the Earth and its inhabitants, and to provide individuals with the information and tools to make informed decisions on how to "walk softly and treat the Earth's creatures gently". The Detroit Zoo hosted a "Sowing Seeds Humane Education" workshop, presented by the Institute for Humane Education. The Sowing Seeds Workshop is designed to train educators to effectively teach critical thinking about social justice, environmental ethics and animal protection, and thereby enhance their students' understanding that their choices make an impact on themselves, other people, other species and the Earth. Sowing Seeds offers participants dynamic activities and practical tips and demonstrations of the effectiveness of humane education. A year-round gardening project was initiated with a group of teens at Children's Village. The students learn about native plants, organic gardening, creating wildlife-friendly habitats, and how to incorporate eco-friendly items into the landscape. Additionally, we're working to instill reverence and respect for the wildlife that's encountered in and around the garden through a photography project. The first Growing Up WILD workshop was held at the Detroit Zoo in the DTE Energy Foundation Humane Science Lab. Project WILD is an interdisciplinary conservation and environmental education program emphasizing wildlife. The goal of Project WILD is to provide strategies for teachers to assist students of any age in developing awareness, knowledge, skills and commitment to result in informed decisions, responsible behavior, and constructive actions concerning the wildlife and the environment. This program is closely connected to No Child Left Inside. There are only 61 Project WILD/Project Aquatic Facilitators in the state of Michigan and the Detroit Zoological Society is fortunate to have three certified facilitators. The first Green Team Movie Night was held. Zoo staff and volunteers watched Garbage: The Revolution Starts at Home, a documentary that discusses how our personal choices can have a big impact on the planet. The goal is for Zoo staff to be familiar with issues facing animals and the planet and things that can be done to help lessen our ecological footprint.

The Detroit Zoological Society continues to inspire the community with engaging, meaningful and memorable experiences. During the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year, the DZS had record breaking attendance, opened a 3-D/4-D Theater and hosted a temporary Dinosauria experience at the Detroit Zoo. DINOSAURIA OPENS AT THE DETROIT ZOO MAY 13. Nineteen life-like animatronic dinosaurs that roar, snarl and move have taken up residence at the Detroit Zoo for the summer to provide a thrilling experience for visitors of all ages. Visitors enter a veritable "Zoorassic Park" as they travel back in time along a lush, winding, three-acre DinoTrail recreating prehistoric life. Enormous primeval creatures lurk at every turn, beginning with the mighty Megalosaurus and ending with the tremendous Tyrannosaurus rex. PALEOJOE APPEARS AT DETROIT ZOO'S DINOSAURIA. Michigan paleontologist, author and storyteller Joseph "PaleoJoe" Kchodl made the first of several appearances at the Detroit Zoo's Dinosauria experience. PaleoJoe could be found on the three-acre DinoTrail educating visitors about dinosaurs and fossils. He also gave fossil presentations, including a bone-cleaning demonstration, at the Ford Education Center. PaleoJoe has taught fossil programs to schoolchildren throughout the Midwest and has authored several books on fossils and dinosaurs. DETROIT ZOO OPENS WILD ADVENTURE 3-D/4-D THEATER. Detroit Zoo visitors are literally "blown away" by the 126-seat Wild Adventure 3-D/4-D Theater. The first and only theater of its kind at any Michigan zoo delivers a high-definition viewing experience in 3-D with 7.1 digital audio surround sound, enhanced with full-sensory 4-D special effects such as wind, mist and scents. The new permanent attraction debuted with the visually stunning wildlife adventure "Wild World Africa". ZOO BOO FEATURES NINE NIGHTS OF 'SPOOKTACULAR' FUN. The Detroit Zoo's annual "merry-not-scary" Zoo Boo celebration returns each Halloween season, featuring a festively decorated half-mile trick-or-treat trail through the front of the park. Elaborate pumpkin displays line the treat trail, where greeters pass out goodies to costume-clad children at treat stations along the route. A trail of eerie fog and mysterious sounds lead through a spooky graveyard to the Haunted Reptile House, where friendly witches, vampires and other monsters take up residence for the Halloween season. The Ghouly Games Tent features Halloween-themed games, prizes, arts and crafts and a hay maze. WILDLIFE PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE YEAR EXHIBITION MAKES NORTH AMERICAN DEBUT AT DETROIT ZOO. The 2009 Wildlife Photographer of the Year exhibition, a collection of images from the world's largest and most prestigious wildlife photography competition, made its North American premiere at the Detroit Zoo's Ford Education Center on December 16, 2009. The exhibition featured 95 photographs dramatically displayed as illuminated large-format color transparencies. The winning images, chosen from a record 43,135 entries, represented 83 photographers from 24 countries. WINTER WEEKENDS ARE WILD AT THE DETROIT ZOO - Visitors experience the magic of the Detroit Zoo in the wintertime on Wild Winter Weekends in January, February and March. The annual series of family-friendly events feature children's music, keeper talks, games and crafts. All activities are free with regular Zoo admission. VISITORS FLOCK TO DETROIT ZOO IN 2009 FOR A DOSE OF VITAMIN Z. Detroit Zoo attendance was 1,271,663 in 2009, compared to 1,114,221 in 2008, a 14 percent increase. This represents the fourth consecutive year-to-year increase in attendance - which has exceeded one million since 2006 - and the second-highest recorded attendance. In addition, membership increased by more than 11 percent year to year, ending 2009 with 56,064 member households compared to 50,306 in 2008.

The Detroit Zoological Society continues to demonstrate organizational excellence consistent with a commitment to outstanding service, progressive resource management and environment leadership. The Detroit Zoological Society was recognized during the April 1, 2009 - March 31, 2010 calendar year in the following areas: DETROIT ZOO NO. 1 IN NATIONAL GOOGLE CONTEST. More people would enjoy a virtual tour of the Detroit Zoo than any other theme park or zoo in the United States, according to results of the Google Street View "Trike" contest. With more than 15,000 votes, the Detroit Zoo was the national winner in the theme park/zoo category. Google asked its users to submit nominations for pedestrian-only locations they'd most like to see on its popular map feature in the categories of theme parks and zoos, parks and trails, university campuses, pedestrian malls, landmarks and sports venues. From more than 25,000 submissions, Google narrowed the selections to finalists in each category and invited the public to cast their votes online. DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY AD CAMPAIGN WINS GOLD EFFIE AWARD. The Detroit Zoological Society's "Worth Keeping" advertising campaign won a Gold Effie at the 2009 Effie Awards ceremony in New York. The campaign won in the Non-Profit/Pro Bono/Public Service category. Prior to the campaign, the DZS faced a financial crisis and needed Detroit-area residents to support a ballot proposal to provide long-term funding for the Detroit Zoo. The multi-media campaign leveraged the positive and deep emotions residents already had for the Zoo around the central theme, "Our Zoo is Worth Keeping". DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY FLIES AWAY WITH PLUME AWARD. The DZS received a 2009 Plume Award from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) Avian Scientific Advisory Group for its African spoonbill breeding program. The Plume Award recognizes excellence in avian husbandry and commitment to the long-term management of birds in AZA zoos. The DZS's submission of its African spoonbill captive propagation program focused on eight years of problem-solving in breeding, which resulted in the rearing of 16 chicks. DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY HONORED FOR CONSERVATION OF GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER. The DZS received the 2009 North American Conservation Award from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) for its coordination of the Great Lakes piping plover salvage captive rearing program. The significant achievement award honors the DZS's efforts to conserve the endangered bird. The Great Lakes population of piping plovers has been listed as federally endangered under the U.S. Endangered Species Act since 1986. DETROIT ZOO EARTH DAY EVENT EMPHASIZES 'NO CHILD LEFT INSIDE. The Detroit Zoo hosted its Earth Day celebration on Saturday, April 18, 2009. The annual event is an educational experience dedicated to celebrating wildlife and educating Zoo visitors about environmental conservation. The Earth Day celebration featured special educational activities in support of "No Child Left Inside", a national campaign to expose children to outdoor learning activities and highlight the importance of environmental education. The Zoo-wide celebration included earth-friendly crafts, an endangered species scavenger hunt, animal enrichment activities and zookeeper talks. BELLE ISLE NATURE ZOO PARTICIPATES IN YOUTH DAY. The Belle Isle Nature Zoo participated in Metro Detroit Youth Day on Wednesday, July 8, 2009, on Belle Isle. The Nature Zoo sponsored live performances by the award-winning Mosaic Youth Theatre of Detroit, highlighting humane education in a way that is fun and entertaining for audiences of all ages. In addition, Detroit Zoological Society Education Specialist David Gakure spoke about his 17 years educating adventurers as a naturalist guide in Nairobi, Kenya. The largest youth event in Michigan, Metro Detroit Youth Day unites the area's youth from all backgrounds. The annual event includes youth leadership, sports clinics, games, contests, anti-substance abuse activities, scholarship awards, motivational speakers and entertainment. VITAMIN Z: PART OF A COMPLETE CHILDHOOD FOUND ONLY AT THE DETROIT ZOO. There are certain elements essential to every childhood: eating fruits and vegetables, getting plenty of exercise, drinking lots of water - and visiting the Detroit Zoo. The Zoo's new advertising campaign adds "Vitamin Z" to the list of nutrients essential to a complete childhood. The "Vitamin Z" campaign highlights immersive experiences found only at the Detroit Zoo - including the Giraffe Encounter, Australian Outback Adventure, Arctic Ring of Life and Butterfly Garden - and captures the range of emotions kids feel when they encounter the animals. CLEAN, GREEN SOLAR POWERED MACHINE REPLACES GAS GUZZLER AT DETROIT ZOO. The Detroit Zoological Society continues on the road to "green" by replacing its gas-powered golf carts with solar/electric hybrid carts. The 40 golf carts are used by the Detroit Zoo's animal, maintenance, landscaping, park safety, education, events, marketing and public relations staffs to transport equipment and people around the 125-acre Zoo. By replacing fossil fuel with solar power, the Zoo is reducing its carbon dioxide emissions from golf carts by an estimated 450 pounds a year. The new carts boast a regenerative braking system that allows power to go back into the cart each time the brakes are engaged. The solar panels convert sunlight into electricity, reducing the need for standard outlet charging. DETROIT ZOO HOSTS MOSAIC YOUTH THEATER PERFORMANCES. The Mosaic Youth Theatre of Detroit performed "Zoo Medleys" and "Agent OOPaw: The Return of the Seal" on various weekends throughout the summer at the Detroit Zoo. The Mosaic Youth Theatre of Detroit is an award-winning professional performing arts training program whose mission is to empower young people and maximize their potential through professional performing arts. DETROIT ZOO POSTER COMPETITION ARTWORK TO BE EXHIBITED. Fifty-four poster designs were submitted by students from the College for Creative Studies (CCS) for the 2009 Detroit Zoo Poster Competition. The poster designs were judged by a panel of jurors from the Detroit Zoological Society, CCS and Doner Advertising. Award selection criteria included artistic merit, originality, creativity, innovation, and adherence and relevance to the competition theme. DETROIT ZOO'S MAYOR OF AMPHIBIVILLE LEAPS INTO OFFICE. The Detroit Zoo elected a Mayor of Amphibiville for a two-year term. Amphibiville is a two-acre wetland village that is home to the National Amphibian Conservation Center. The new Mayor, a self-proclaimed frog lover since the age of 3, built her own home nature center and has years of experience observing frogs, toads and turtles in her backyard pond. She hopes to someday become a marine biologist. The Zoo invited candidates ages 6-12 who live in Michigan to enter the race for Mayor of Amphibiville in the form of a 100-word essay describing their qualifications for the position.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Description of Classes of Members or Stockholders
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: PAYING DETROIT ZOOLOICAL SOCIETY MEMBERS RECEIVE BENEFITS INCLUDING FREE ADMISSION TO THE DETROIT ZOO, DISCOUNTED ADMISSION TO PARTICIPATING ZOOS AND AQUARUIMS ACROSS THE COUNTRY, 10% DISCOUNT IN THE GIFT SHOP, AND A TAX DEDUCTION TO THE EXTENT ALLOWED BY LAW. CLASSES OF MEMBERSHIPS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: INDIVIDUAL ($48/$65), SINGLE PARENT ($70) FAMILY/GRANDPARENT ($79), SUPPORTER ($150), AND RENAISSANCE CIRCLE ($1,200+). IN ADDITION TO THE BENEFITS RECEIVED BY THE PAYING MEMBERS, THE MEMBERS ALSO HAVE CERTAIN VOTING AND DECISION MAKING RIGHTS. THIS INCLUDES THE ABILITY TO ATTEND THE ANNUAL MEETING AND CALL SPECIAL MEETINGS. THE ANNUAL MEETING OF THE MEMBERS IS HELD ON A DATE FIXED BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OR BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE WITHIN THE SECOND QUARTER OF EACH FISCAL YEAR. SPECIAL MEETINGS OF THE MEMBERS MAY ALSO BE CALLED BY THE CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, THE PRESIDENT, A MAJORITY OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OR OF THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, OR BY NOT LESS THAN ONE-TENTH OF THE MEMBERS. AT EACH MEETING OF THE MEMBERS OF THE SOCIETY, EACH MEMBER SHALL BE ENTITLED TO CAST ONE VOTE ON EACH MATTER SUBMITTED FOR MEMBERSHIP ACTION; THIS VOTE MAY BE BY PROXY EXECUTED IN WRITING BY THE MEMBER OR BY HIS DULY AUTHORIZED ATTORNEY-IN-FACT. NO PROXY SHALL BE VALID AFTER ELEVEN (11) MONTHS FROM THE DATE OF ITS EXECUTION UNLESS OTHERWISE PROVIDED IN THE PROXY. NO PERSON MAY ACT AS A PROXY UNLESS SUCH PERSON IS A MEMBER OF THE SOCIETY. ALL PRIVILEGES OF MEMBERSHIP (OTHER THAN VOTING) ARE SUBJECT TO SUCH RULES AND REGULATIONS THAT MAY BE ADOPTED BY A MAJORITY VOTE OF THE ENTIRE BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Description of Classes of Persons and the Nature of Their Rights
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Zoological Society Board governs, develops policies and strategy and oversees all society operations and activities. The committee shall be appointed by the board chairperson and ratified by the board of trustees. The Committee shall consist of at least five persons, including the board chairperson, the Director/CEO and at least two other board members. The chairperson of the committee shall be a member of the board of trustees. 1. The Governance and Nominating Committee will be responsible for the recruitment, selection, nominating, orientation and evaluation of board members of the Detroit Zoological Society. 2. Maintain an awareness of the needs of the board and/or its affiliate organizations for executive and board talents. 3. Plan board members' development, including recruitment, orientation, education, and evaluation of their effectiveness. 4. Identify and select candidates for committees of the board using criteria for board service as a guide. 5. Provide an orientation program conducted by management for new board members. 6. Periodically conduct an assessment to determine board educational needs. The Director/CEO will be responsible for researching and updating the committee on educational opportunities. 7. Conduct board self-evaluations. 8. Review the performance of board members prior to re-appointment. 9. Confirm compliance with the DZS conflict of interest policy. 10. Meet quarterly, or as needed.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Describe the Process used by Management &/or Governing Body to Review 990
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE INFORMATION REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE IRS FORM 990 IS PREPARED BY THE DETROIT ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY'S ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE CONTROLLER. THE INForMATION IS FORWARDED TO an accounting firm WHO IMPORTs THE INFORMATION INTO THE APPROPRIATE SCHEDULES. A REVIEW IS PERFORMED BY THE Accounting firm's TAX STAFF TO ENSURE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS. AFTER THE INTIAL REVIEW IS PERFORMED, A DRAFT IS PROVIDED TO THE CFO AND CONTROLLER FOR REVIEW. A DRAFT IS THEN EMAILED TO THE AUDIT, executive and finance COMMITTEEs ("the committees") FOR REVIEW. A CONFERENCE CALL OR MEETING IS COORDINATED TO DISCUSS THE FORM AND ADDRESS ANY QUESTIONS THAT MAY RESULT DURING THE cOMMITTEEs' REVIEW OF THE FORM. Subsequent to the meeting of the committees, THE AUDIT COMMITTEE CHAIR INFORMS THE CFO THAT THE FORM CAN BE FILED ON THE ORGANIZATION'S BEHALF. A BOARD RESOLUTION IS NOT REQUIRED IN ORDER FOR THE FORM 990 TO BE FILED. THE Accounting firm is then INForMED THAT THE FORM IS READY TO BE FILED WITH THE IRS. THE accounting firm PROVIDEs A FINAL COPY OF THE FORM THAT NEEDS TO BE SIGNED BY THE CEO AND THE PREPARER FROM THE INDENDENT AUDITOR'S OFFICE. ONCE THE APPROPRIATE SIGNATURES ARE OBTAINED, THE FORM IS FILED WITH THE IRS AND STATE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Description of Process to Monitor Transactions for Conflicts of Interest
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Conflict of Interest Policy is distributed annually to employees and board members. Employees receive a copy during an all employee meeting. employees are given a week to read the policy, and complete the questionnaire. Employees are required to submit the completed information to the Human Resources Department. Board members are given a copy of the conflict of interest policy at the annual board retreat which takes place in October. they are asked to read the policy, complete the questionnaire and return it to the Chief Executive Officer's administrative assistant. Disclosure in the Society is made to the Board Chair and/or the Chief Executive Officer of the Society who shall determine whether a conflict exists and is material, and if the matters are material, bring them to the attention of the Board. The Board Chair and/or the Chief Executive Officer shall consider whether a conflict exists and is material, and in the presence of an existing material conflict, whether the contemplated transaction may be authorized as just, fair and reasonable to the Society. The decision of the Board Chair and/or the Chief Executive Officer of the Society on these matters will rest in heir sole discretion, and their concern must be the welfare of the Society and the advancement of its purpose.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Offices & Positions for Which Process was Used, & Year Process was Begun
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Detroit Zoological society (DZS) engaged consultant, Towers Perrin, to assess a competitive salary analysis of non-union, salaried benchmark positions and develop salary structures and ranges for these positions. Job grades and salary ranges, including minimum, midpoint and maximum were established for each position. Upon determining a wage for a new-hire, an individual's salary is set within the range considering the market value of the position (based on the role's primary responsibilities), individual characteristics (experience, performance, etc.) and internal value. Salary is not to be lower than the minimum established wage of the pay grade and range. If a new-hire is to be brought in higher that the established midpoint wage of the pay grade and range, it must be approved by Human Resources and a member of the Executive Leadership Team (ELT). Salary is not to exceed the established maximum wage of the pay grade and range. The approval would be noted on the personnel request form; documentation of the approval would then be maintained in the new hire's personnel file.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: AVAIL OF GOV DOCS, COI POLICY, & FINANCIAL STMTS TO GEN PUBLIC
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The financial statements, governing documents and conflict of interest policy are not generally available to the public unless a specific written request is made.
